subsection.title: Logarithms are Exponents
subsection.p: Because logarithms are actually exponents, they have several properties that can be derived from the laws of exponents. Here are the laws we will need at present.

li.p: To multiply two powers with the same base, add the exponents and leave the base unchanged. a^m \cdot a^n = a^{m+n}
To divide two powers with the same base, subtract the exponents and leave the base unchanged. \frac{a^m}{a^n} = a^{m-n}
To raise a power to a power, keep the same base and multiply the exponents. \left(a^m\right)^n = a^{mn}

subsection.p: Each of these laws corresponds to one of three properties of logarithms.

subsection.title: Using the Properties of Logarithms
subsection.p: Of course, these properties are useful not so much for computing logs but rather for simplifying expressions that contain variables. We will use them to solve exponential equations. But first, we will practice applying the properties.

statement.p: Write ~~\log_{b}\sqrt{{xy}} as an expression in simpler logs.
Write \log_{b}\dfrac{x}{y^2} as an expression in simpler logs.
Answer: \log_b+\cdot\log_b

subsection.p: We can also use the properties of logarithms to combine sums and differences of logarithms into one logarithm.

statement.p: Express ~~3(\log_b x - \log_b y) as a single logarithm with a coefficient of 1.

solution.p: We begin by applying Property (2) to combine the logs. 3(\log_b x - \log_b y) \amp = 3 \log_{b}\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right) \amp \amp \blert{\text{Apply Property 3.}} \amp =\log_{b}\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)^3 Thus, 3(\log_b x - \log_b y) = \log_{b}\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)^3.

statement.p: Express 2\log_b x + 4\log_{b}{(x + 3)} as a single logarithm with a coefficient of 1.
Answer: \log_b

True or False.
The log of a product is equal to the sum of the logs of the factors.
The log of a quotient is the equal to the difference of the logs.
The log of a power is equal to the exponent times the log of the base.
The distributive law applies to the operation of taking a logarithm of a sum or difference.

subsection.title: Solving Logarithmic Equations
subsection.p: A logarithmic equationlogarithmic equation is one in which the variable appears inside of a logarithm. For example, \log_4 x = 3 is a log equation.
If there is only one log involved, we can use the conversion formula to write the equation in exponential form.

statement.p: Solve ~\log_5{(5-3x)} = 3

warning.p: We cannot take a logarithm of a negative number or zero. This is because the output of an exponential function is always positive.
For example suppose that \log_5{-25} = x. Then 5^x = -25. But this is impossible, because 5^x cannot be negative. Thus, the log of a negative number (or zero) is undefined.
Because of this fact, extraneous solutions can arise when we solve logarithmic equations.

subsection.p: By using the properties of logarithms, we can now solve equations that arise in exponential growth and decay models, no matter what base the exponential function uses.
